sen.j: 水度神社（みとじんじゃ）は、京都府城陽市寺田水度坂に鎮座する神社である。
sen.e: "Mito-jinja Shrine" is a shrine in Teradamitosaka, Joyo City, Kyoto Prefecture.
"Mito-jinja Shrine" is a shrine in Teradamitosaka, Joyo City, Kyoto Prefecture.
"Mito-jinja Shrine" is a shrine in Teradamitosaka, Joyo City, Kyoto Prefecture.

sen.j: 鴻ノ巣山のふもとにある。
sen.e: It is at the foot of Konosu-yama Mountain.
Its at the foot of Mount Konosu-yama.
sen.cmt: exactly proper would be "mount Konosu" without "yama" as "yama" is redundant even though it is a Japanese word. Since this is a mix of english and Japanese, I left "yama" attached
sen.e: Its at the foot of Mount Konosu-yama.

sen.j: 「山城国風土記」逸文に、「久世の郡水渡の社祗社」とあることから、風土記が編さんされた奈良時代には存在したと考えられる。
sen.e: It is described as 'Kuze no gun Mito no Kunitsuyashiro' in the lost writings of "Yamashiro no kuni Fudoki," suggesting that it existed in the Nara period, when the fudoki was compiled.
This shrine is described as 'Kuze no gun Mito no Kunitsuyashiro' in the lost writings of "Yamashiro no kuni Fudoki," suggesting that it existed in the Nara period, when the fudoki was compiled.
sen.cmt: "This shrine" replaces "it" for clarity concerning the subject. It is common to repeat the subject word, in this case "the shrine" in lines that become further removed from the first line that describes the subject, otherwise, it may confuse the reader
sen.e: This shrine is described as 'Kuze no gun Mito no Kunitsuyashiro' in the lost writings of "Yamashiro no kuni Fudoki," suggesting that it existed in the Nara period, when the fudoki was compiled.

sen.j: 創祀は平安時代初期といわれる。
sen.e: First enshrinement is believed to be in the early Heian period.
First enshrinement is believed to be in the early Heian period.
First enshrinement is believed to be in the early Heian period.

sen.j: 平安時代前期に成立した延喜式には、「水度神社三座」と記されている。
sen.e: In the Engishiki (List of Official Shrines), which was established in the first half of the Heian period, it is listed as 'Mito-jinja Shrine sanza.'
In the Engishiki (List of Official Shrines), which was established in the first half of the Heian period, it is listed as 'Mito-jinja Shrine sanza.'
In the Engishiki (List of Official Shrines), which was established in the first half of the Heian period, it is listed as 'Mito-jinja Shrine sanza.'

sen.j: 1873年（明治6年）に村社、1882年（明治15年）に郷社、1907年（明治40年）には府社に昇格した。
sen.e: It advanced to township shrine in 1873, village shrine in 1882, and prefectural shrine in 1907.
It advanced to a township shrine in 1873, a village shrine in 1882, and a prefectural shrine in 1907.
sen.cmt: "a" added to be grammatically correct, and to set apart each promotion of the shrine
sen.e: It advanced to a township shrine in 1873, a village shrine in 1882, and a prefectural shrine in 1907.

sen.j: 現在は社格は廃止され、神社本庁に属し、「宗教法人 水度神社」と称している。
sen.e: Currently, the shrine ranking is abolished, and it belongs to the Jinja-Honcho (The Association of Shinto Shrines) under the name 'Religious corporation, Mito-jinja Shrine.'
Currently, shrine ranking has been abolished, and it now belongs to the Jinja-Honcho (The Association of Shinto Shrines) under the name 'Religious corporation, Mito-jinja Shrine.'
Currently, shrine ranking has been abolished, and it now belongs to the Jinja-Honcho (The Association of Shinto Shrines) under the name 'Religious corporation, Mito-jinja Shrine.'

sen.j: 国指定の重要文化財になっている本殿は正面一間、側面二間の変化に富んだ流造破風様式で屋根は檜皮葺で正面に大きな千鳥破風がある。
sen.e: The main shrine, which is a designated cultural property of Japan, is a Ryuzohafu yoshiki rich in variation, with one ken (counter used to number the gaps between pillars) on the front side and two kens on the sides, and the roof is a cypress bark roof with a large chidori hafu in the front.

The main shrine, which is designated as a cultural property of Japan, is Ryuzohafu yoshiki rich in variation, with one ken (counter used to number the gaps between pillars) on the front side and two kens on the sides, and the roof is a cypress bark roof with a large chidori hafu in the front.

The main shrine, which is designated as a cultural property of Japan, is Ryuzohafu yoshiki rich in variation, with one ken (counter used to number the gaps between pillars) on the front side and two kens on the sides, the roof is a cypress bark roof with a large chidori hafu in the front.

sen.j: また、庇の正面中央には透かし彫りの唐草と笹りんどうをあしらった欄間がつけられ、簡素にして優美な建物となっている。
sen.e: Additionally, in the center of the eave, there is a transom decorated with fretwork of arabesque along with bamboo leaves and gentian, creating a simple but elegant building.
Additionally, in the center of the eave, there is a transom decorated with fretwork of arabesque along with bamboo leaves and gentian, creating a simple but elegant building.
Additionally, in the center of the eave, there is a transom decorated with fretwork of arabesque along with bamboo leaves and gentian, creating a simple but elegant building.

sen.j: 社伝棟札によれば室町時代の1448年（文安5年）建立になり城陽市内で最も古い建造物である。
sen.e: According to the ridge tag with history of the shrine inscribed, it was built in 1448, and is the oldest building in Joyo City.
According to the ridge tag with history of the shrine inscribed, it was built in 1448, and is the oldest building in Joyo City.
According to the ridge tag with the history of the shrine inscribed, it was built in 1448, and is the oldest building in Joyo City.
sen.cmt: 文法。定冠詞必要。 - “ history of”=>” the history of”

sen.j: 祭神は、旧寺田村の産土神で、天照皇大御神（あまてらすすめおおみかみ）・高御産靈神（たかみむすびのかみ）・少童豐玉姫命（わだつみとよたまひめのみこと）となっている。
sen.e: Its enshrined deity is the guardian deity of birthplace for the former Terada Village, and are Amaterasu Sume Omikami, Takami musubi no kami, and Wadatsumitoyotamahime no mikoto.
Its enshrined deities are the guardian deities of the birthplace for the former Terada Village, and are; Amaterasu Sume Omikami, Takami musubi no kami, and Wadatsumitoyotamahime no mikoto.
Its enshrined deities are the following guardian deities of the former Terada Village: Amaterasu Sume Omikami, Takami musubi no kami, and Wadatsumitoyotamahime no mikoto.
sen.cmt: “guardian deities of the birthplace for the former Terada Village,”の意味を明確に訳し直しました。。

sen.j: 例年9月30日から10月2日
sen.e: From September 30 to October 2 yearly
From September 30 to October 2 yearly
From September 30 to October 2 annually

sen.j: 9月30日の「オイデ」の神の迎えは、オタビから行列により子ども神奥を中心に、祭具などの順番や分担が決まっている整然とした行列で行われる。
sen.e: Welcoming the god in the 'Oide' on September 30, is performed as an orderly parade starting at the Otabi (place where the sacred palanquin is lodged during a festival), mainly by children and Shino, with the order and allotment predefined for equipments used in the festival.
sen.cmt: 「子ども神奥」が解釈できませんでした。
sen.e: Welcoming the god in the 'Oide' on September 30, is performed as an orderly parade starting at the Otabi (place where the sacred palanquin is lodged during a festival), mainly by children and Shino, with the order and allotment predefined for equipment used in the festival.

Welcoming the god in the 'Oide' on September 30, is performed as an orderly parade starting at the Otabi (place where the sacred palanquin is lodged during a festival), mainly by children and Shino, with the order and allotment predefined for equipment used in the festival.

sen.j: 10月1日の「ヨミヤ」の夜は、オタビの神前で巫女が鉄湯釜の湯を笹によって参拝者に振りまかれ、安全を祈る「湯立て神事」が行われる。
sen.e: On the night of 'Yomiya' (eve of a festival vigil) on October 1, the shrine maiden sprinkles hot water from the Tetsuyugama (iron pot) before god using bamboo leaves, and 'Yutateshinji' is performed, praying for safety.

On the night of 'Yomiya' (eve of a festival vigil) on October 1, the shrine maiden sprinkles hot water from the Tetsuyugama (iron pot) before god using bamboo leaves, and 'Yutateshinji' is performed, praying for safety.

On the night of 'Yomiya' (eve of a festival vigil) on October 1, the shrine maiden sprinkles hot water from the Tetsuyugama (iron pot) before the god using bamboo leaves, and 'Yutateshinji' is performed, praying for safety.
sen.cmt: 文法。定冠詞必要。 “god”=>” the god”

sen.j: 10月2日の「マツリ」は、神は神社へと行列により送られる。
sen.e: In the 'Matsuri' on October 2, the parade sends god off to the shrine.
In the 'Matsuri' on October 2, the parade sends the god off to the shrine.
In the 'Matsuri' on October 2, the parade sends the god off to the shrine.

sen.j: 水度神社には京都府登録文化財の「おかげ踊り図絵馬」が残っている。
sen.e: At the Mito-jinja Shrine, Kyoto Prefecture's registered cultural property, 'Okage odorizu ema,' remains.
At the Mito-jinja Shrine, Kyoto Prefecture's registered cultural property, 'Okage odorizu ema,' remains.
At the Mito-jinja Shrine, Kyoto Prefecture's registered cultural property, 'Okage odorizu ema,' remains.

sen.j: 絵馬には1830年（文政13年）11月1日に寺田村北東町の人々が水度神社に奉納したおかげ踊りの様子が描かれている。
sen.e: On the ema (votive picture), the scene of Okage-odori dance presented to Mito-jinja Shrine by the people of Hokuto Town, Terada Village on November 1, 1830 is drawn.
On the ema (votive picture), a scene of the Okage-odori dance presented to Mito-jinja Shrine by the people of Hokuto Town, Terada Village on November 1, 1830, is drawn.
On the ema (votive picture), a scene of the Okage-odori dance presented to Mito-jinja Shrine by the people of Hokuto Town, Terada Village on November 1, 1830, is drawn.

sen.j: 江戸時代に全国で流行した伊勢神宮への集団参拝「おかげ参り」の後によく見られたとされる「おかげ踊り」がこの地でも行われていたことを示している。
sen.e: It shows that 'Okage-odori dance,' which was often performed following 'Okage mairi,' or group visits to Ise-jingu Shrine, which became popular nationwide in Edo period, was performed here as well.
It shows that the 'Okage-odori dance,' was often performed following 'Okage mairi,' or group visits to Ise-jingu Shrine, which became popular nationwide in Edo period, was performed here as well.
sen.cmt: slightly revised for clarity and correctness
sen.e: Even today, it is being revived and handed down to subsequent generations by the local 'Okage-odori hozonkai' (Okage-odori dance preservation group), and the dance is presented at the Mito-jinja Shrine.
sen.cmt: 意味が不明確。“ handed down to generations” => “ handed down to subsequent generations”

sen.j: 城陽市では寺田や青谷近辺で昭和の初め頃まで行事ごとに踊られていたようである。
sen.e: In Joyo City, the dance took place after every event until the beginning of Showa era around Terada and Aoya regions.
In Joyo City, the dance took place after every event until the beginning of Showa era around the Terada and Aoya regions.
In Joyo City, the dance took place after every event until the beginning of Showa era around the Terada and Aoya regions.

sen.j: 現在でも、地元の「おかげ踊り保存会」により復活・伝承され、水度神社で踊りを奉納している。
sen.e: Even today, it is being revived and handed down by the local 'Okage-odori hozonkai' (Okage-odori dance preservation group), and the dance is presented at the Mito-jinja Shrine.
Even today, it is being revived and handed down to generations by the local 'Okage-odori hozonkai' (Okage-odori dance preservation group), and the dance is presented at the Mito-jinja Shrine.

Even today, it is being revived and handed down to subsequent generations by the local 'Okage-odori hozonkai' (Okage-odori dance preservation group), and the dance is presented at the Mito-jinja Shrine.
sen.cmt: "handed down through generations" -> "handed down to subsequent generations" に変更しました。

sen.j: 水度神社には城陽市指定文化財の「鉄湯釜」、「大般若経」がある。
sen.e: Tetsuyugama' and 'Daihannyakyo' (Great Perfection of Wisdom Sutra) at the Mito-jinja Shrine are designated cultural properties of Joyo City.
Tetsuyugama' and 'Daihannyakyo' (the Great Perfection of Wisdom Sutra) at the Mito-jinja Shrine are designated cultural properties of Joyo City.
Tetsuyugama' and 'Daihannyakyo' (the Great Perfection of Wisdom Sutra) at the Mito-jinja Shrine are designated cultural properties of Joyo City.

sen.j: 「鉄湯釜」は、湯立て神事に使われていたと考えられ、銘文から1425年（応永32年）に作られたことがわかる。
sen.e: Tetsuyugama' is believed to have been used for Yutateshinji, and was made in 1425 according to the inscription.
Tetsuyugama' is believed to have been used for Yutateshinji, and was made in 1425 according to the inscription.
Tetsuyugama' is believed to have been used for Yutateshinji, and was made in 1425 according to the inscription.

sen.j: 「大般若経」は、全六百一巻「経箱七箱」有、鎌倉時代前期にさかのぼる書写経で、村落における信仰の歴史を知る貴重な資料となっている。
sen.e: The 'Daihannyakyo,' which comes in 601 volumes and 'Kyobako nanahako' (seven boxes for the sutras), is a hand-copied sutra dating back to the early Kamakura period, and is a valuable source for knowing the history of faith in villages.

The 'Daihannyakyo,' which comes in 601 volumes and 'Kyobako nanahako' (seven boxes for the sutras), is a hand-copied sutra dating back to the early Kamakura period, and is a valuable source for knowing the history of faith in villages.

The 'Daihannyakyo,' which comes in 601 volumes and 'Kyobako nanahako' (seven boxes for the sutras), is a hand-copied sutra dating back to the early Kamakura period, and is a valuable source for learning the history of faith in villages.
sen.cmt: 表現スタイル “for knowing” => “for learning”

sen.j: （寺田今堀の歴史民族資料館寄託）
sen.e: (Entrusted to the Rekishi Minzoku Shiryokan (History and Folklore Museum) in Teradaimabori)
(Entrusted to the Rekishi Minzoku Shiryokan (History and Folklore Museum) in Teradaimabori)
(Entrusted to the Rekishi Minzoku Shiryokan (History and Folklore Museum) in Teradaimabori)

sen.j: JR城陽駅から南へ約200mの場所に旧大和街道に接して立つ「一の鳥居」がある。
sen.e: Ichi no torii' (the first archway) stands along the former Yamato-kaido Street, about 200 m south of the JR Joyo Station.
Ichi no torii' (the first gate) stands along the former Yamato-kaido Street, about 200 meters south of the Joyo JR Station.
sen.cmt: revised, "archway" refers to the half or partial shape of a circle, so it's not suitable for describing a torii "gate"
sen.e: Ichi no torii' (the first gate) stands along the former Yamato-kaido Street, about 200 meters south of the Joyo JR Station.

sen.j: ここから東へ鴻ノ巣山のふもとにある「二の鳥居」を経て約600m先に水度神社本殿がある。
sen.e: From there, the main building of the Mito-jinja Shrine is about 600 m to the east via the 'Ni no torii' (the second archway) at the foot of Konosu-yama Mountain.
From there, the main building of the Mito-jinja Shrine is about 600 meters to the east via the 'Ni no torii' (the second gate) at the foot of Mount Konosu-yama.
From there, the main building of the Mito-jinja Shrine is about 600 meters to the east via the 'Ni no torii' (the second gate) at the foot of Mount Konosu-yama.

sen.j: 参道は神社へ向かって緩い上り坂道になっている。
sen.e: The sando is a gentle ascent to the shrine.
The sando is a gentle ascent to the shrine.
The sando is a gentle ascent to the shrine.

sen.j: かつて参道にはお茶屋が軒を連ね、参拝客で賑わっていたと言われている。
sen.e: There used to be teashops along the sando, busy with visitors.
There used to be teashops along the sando, busy with visitors.
There used to be teashops along the sando, busy with visitors.

sen.j: この参道は概ね市の中心部に位置しているが、参道の両側は松の古木の並木、神社の周りはアカマツを交えたシイ林で、周辺が宅地化した中で、豊かな自然環境を保持しているとして、水度神社と参道の松並木が「京都の自然200選」に選ばれた。
sen.e: The sando is more or less at the center of the city, but on both sides of the sando are rows of old pine trees, and the area around the shrine is a chinquapin forest with some red pines, and thus, Mito-jinja Shrine and the row of pine trees on the sando were selected as '200 Selected Kyoto Treasures of Nature,' as maintaining a rich natural environment while the surrounding became a residential area.

The sando is more or less at the center of the city, but on both sides of the sando are rows of old pine trees, and the area around the shrine is a chinquapin forest with some red pines, and thus, Mito-jinja Shrine and the row of pine trees on the sando were selected as '200 Selected Kyoto Treasures of Nature,' for maintaining a rich natural environment while the surroundings became a residential area.

The sando is more or less at the center of the city, but on both sides of the sando are rows of old pine trees, and the area around the shrine is a chinquapin forest with some red pines, and thus, Mito-jinja Shrine and the row of pine trees on the sando were selected as '200 Selected Kyoto Treasures of Nature,' for maintaining a rich natural environment while the surroundings became a residential area.

sen.j: JR奈良線城陽駅から東へ1km、京都府立城陽高等学校の北側。
sen.e: 1 km east of the JR Nara line Joyo Station, to the north of Kyoto Prefectural Joyo High School.
1 km east of the Nara Joyo JR Station lin, north of Kyoto Prefectural Joyo High School.
1 km east of the Nara Joyo JR Station lin, north of Kyoto Prefectural Joyo High School.
